docs.title: End-to-End Image Classifier with MLOps
docs.text: Welcome to the documentation for the End-to-End Image Classifier project! This project demonstrates MLOps best practices for building, training, and deploying image classification models.

docs.title: 🎯 Project Overview
docs.text:
This project implements a complete MLOps pipeline for image classification, demonstrating:

  • Standardized Project Structure: Clean, maintainable codebase following industry standards
  • Configuration Management: Flexible experiment configuration with Hydra
  • Data Versioning: Track datasets with DVC
  • Automated Testing: Comprehensive test suite with pytest
  • CI/CD: Automated pipelines with GitHub Actions
  • Continuous ML: Automated model training and reporting with CML
  • Containerization: Docker support for reproducible deployments
  • Documentation: Complete documentation with MkDocs

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started in 3 simple steps:

# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/end-to-end-image-classifier.git
cd end-to-end-image-classifier

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Train your first model
python src/training/train.py

docs.title: Smart Configuration Management
docs.text:
Use Hydra to manage all configurations without touching code:

# Override learning rate
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.001

# Use different model
python src/training/train.py model=resnet

# Switch dataset
python src/training/train.py data=mnist

docs.title: Data Version Control
docs.text:
Never lose track of your datasets:

# Track data with DVC
dvc add data/raw

# Push to remote storage
dvc push

# Pull data from any commit
git checkout <commit>
dvc pull

docs.title: Automated Testing
docs.text:
Ensure code quality with comprehensive tests:

# Run all tests
pytest tests/

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=src tests/

# Run only fast tests
pytest -m "not slow"

docs.title: CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text:
Every push triggers:

  • ✅ Code linting and formatting checks
  • ✅ Unit and integration tests
  • ✅ Model training with performance reporting
  • ✅ Automated deployment (optional)

docs.title: Docker Support
docs.text:
Run anywhere with Docker:

# Build image
docker build -t image-classifier .

# Run training
docker run image-classifier

# Run inference
docker run image-classifier python src/models/predict.py --help

docs.title: Configuration Management with Hydra
docs.text: This project uses Hydra for configuration management, making it easy to run experiments without modifying code.

docs.title: Configuration Structure
docs.text:
configs/
├── config.yaml              # Main configuration
├── model/
│   ├── simple_cnn.yaml     # Simple CNN config
│   └── resnet.yaml         # ResNet config
├── data/
│   ├── cifar10.yaml        # CIFAR-10 dataset config
│   └── mnist.yaml          # MNIST dataset config
└── hyperparameters/
    ├── default.yaml        # Default hyperparameters
    └── fast.yaml           # Fast training config

docs.title: Override Single Parameter
docs.text: python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.01

docs.title: Override Multiple Parameters
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.01 \
  hyperparameters.batch_size=128 \
  hyperparameters.num_epochs=20

docs.title: Use Different Config Group
docs.text:
# Use ResNet model
python src/training/train.py model=resnet

# Use MNIST dataset
python src/training/train.py data=mnist

# Use fast hyperparameters
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters=fast

docs.title: Combine Overrides
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py \
  model=resnet \
  data=mnist \
  hyperparameters=fast

docs.title: Main Config (config.yaml)
docs.text:
defaults:
  - model: simple_cnn
  - data: cifar10
  - hyperparameters: default
  - _self_

seed: 42
device: auto
num_workers: 2

output_dir: ./outputs
model_save_dir: ./models
report_dir: ./reports

log_interval: 10
save_best_only: true
early_stopping_patience: 10

experiment_name: image_classifier
run_name: ${now:%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S}

docs.title: Model Configs
docs.text:
Simple CNN (model/simple_cnn.yaml): 

name: simple_cnn
num_classes: 10
input_channels: 3
dropout: 0.5

ResNet (model/resnet.yaml): 

name: resnet
num_classes: 10
input_channels: 3

docs.title: Data Configs
docs.text:
CIFAR-10 (data/cifar10.yaml): 

name: cifar10
data_dir: ./data/raw
batch_size: 64
val_split: 0.1
image_size: 32
num_classes: 10
input_channels: 3

mean: [0.5, 0.5, 0.5]
std: [0.5, 0.5, 0.5]

classes:
  - airplane
  - automobile
  - bird
  # ... etc

docs.title: Hyperparameter Configs
docs.text:
Default (hyperparameters/default.yaml): 

learning_rate: 0.001
weight_decay: 1e-4
momentum: 0.9
optimizer: adam

num_epochs: 50
batch_size: 64

use_scheduler: true
scheduler_type: step
step_size: 10
gamma: 0.1
min_lr: 1e-6

dropout: 0.5
label_smoothing: 0.0
clip_grad_norm: 1.0

docs.title: Create Custom Experiment Config
docs.text:
Create configs/experiment/my_exp.yaml:

# @package _global_

defaults:
  - override /model: resnet
  - override /data: cifar10
  - override /hyperparameters: default

# Override specific values
hyperparameters:
  learning_rate: 0.005
  num_epochs: 100
  batch_size: 128
  use_scheduler: true
  scheduler_type: cosine

seed: 1234
experiment_name: resnet_cifar10_cosine

Run it:

python src/training/train.py --config-name=experiment/my_exp

docs.title: Access Config in Code
docs.text:
import hydra
from omegaconf import DictConfig

@hydra.main(version_base=None, config_path="../configs", config_name="config")
def main(cfg: DictConfig):
    print(cfg.hyperparameters.learning_rate)
    print(cfg.model.name)
    # Access nested configs easily

docs.title: Print Configuration
docs.text:
# Print full config
python src/training/train.py --cfg job

# Print specific group
python src/training/train.py --cfg job model

docs.title: Composition
docs.text:
Create different combinations:

# Experiment 1: Simple CNN on CIFAR-10
python src/training/train.py \
  model=simple_cnn \
  data=cifar10 \
  experiment_name=exp1_simple_cifar

# Experiment 2: ResNet on MNIST
python src/training/train.py \
  model=resnet \
  data=mnist \
  experiment_name=exp2_resnet_mnist

docs.title: Learning Rate Tuning
docs.text:
# Try different learning rates
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.0001
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.001
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.01

docs.title: Batch Size Tuning
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.batch_size=32 \
  data.batch_size=32

docs.title: Scheduler Experiments
docs.text:
# Step scheduler
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.scheduler_type=step \
  hyperparameters.step_size=15

# Cosine annealing
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.scheduler_type=cosine

# No scheduler
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.use_scheduler=false

docs.title: Regularization Tuning
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters.dropout=0.3 \
  hyperparameters.weight_decay=1e-5 \
  hyperparameters.label_smoothing=0.1

docs.title: Multi-Run
docs.text:
Run multiple experiments with different parameters:

python src/training/train.py -m \
  hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.001,0.01,0.1

This creates separate runs for each learning rate.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Use environment variables in configs:

data_dir: ${oc.env:DATA_DIR,./data/raw}

Then:

export DATA_DIR=/path/to/data
python src/training/train.py

docs.title: Tips & Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Never hardcode values - Use configs for everything
  2. Create experiment configs - Document your experiments
  3. Use meaningful names - experiment_name: resnet_lr001_bs128
  4. Version configs with git - Track what worked
  5. Use defaults - Override only what you need

docs.title: Config Not Found
docs.text:
Make sure you're in the project root:

cd /path/to/end-to-end-image-classifier
python src/training/train.py

docs.title: Override Not Working
docs.text:
Use correct syntax:

# ✅ Correct
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.01

# ❌ Wrong
python src/training/train.py --learning_rate=0.01

docs.title: Nested Override
docs.text:
For nested values:

python src/training/train.py model.dropout=0.3

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide will help you set up the Image Classifier project on your local machine.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.8 or higher: Download Python
  • Git: Download Git
  • pip: Python package installer (usually comes with Python)
  • (Optional) Docker: Download Docker

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/end-to-end-image-classifier.git
cd end-to-end-image-classifier

docs.title: 2. Create Virtual Environment
docs.text:
It's recommended to use a virtual environment to avoid dependency conflicts.

Linux/MacWindows 
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate

python -m venv venv
venv\Scripts\activate

docs.title: 3. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
# Upgrade pip
pip install --upgrade pip

# Install project dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Install the package in editable mode
pip install -e .

docs.title: 4. Verify Installation
docs.text:
Run the tests to ensure everything is working:

pytest tests/ -v -m "not slow"

If all tests pass, you're ready to go! ✅

docs.title: Optional: Setup DVC
docs.text:
If you want to use Data Version Control:

# Initialize DVC
dvc init

# Add remote storage (example: local storage)
dvc remote add -d storage /tmp/dvc-storage

For more details, see the Data Versioning Guide.

docs.title: Optional: Setup Docker
docs.text:
Build the Docker image:

docker build -t image-classifier:latest .

Test the Docker image:

docker run --rm image-classifier:latest python --version

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text: If you plan to contribute to the project:

docs.title: Install Development Dependencies
docs.text:
pip install -r requirements.txt

This includes: - pytest - Testing framework - black - Code formatter - flake8 - Linter - mypy - Type checker

docs.title: Setup Pre-commit Hooks (Optional)
docs.text:
pip install pre-commit
pre-commit install

docs.title: Issue: PyTorch Installation Fails
docs.text:
If you have GPU and want CUDA support:

# CUDA 11.8
pip install torch torchvision --index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu118

# CUDA 12.1
pip install torch torchvision --index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cu121

For CPU-only: 

pip install torch torchvision --index-url https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cpu

docs.title: Issue: Permission Denied
docs.text:
On Linux/Mac, you might need to use sudo or fix permissions:

sudo chown -R $USER:$USER .

docs.title: Issue: Module Not Found
docs.text:
Make sure you installed the package:

pip install -e .

And that your virtual environment is activated.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you've installed the project, check out:

  • Quick Start Guide - Train your first model
  • Configuration Guide - Learn about Hydra configs
  • User Guide - Detailed training instructions

docs.text:

  • GPU: NVIDIA GPU with CUDA support (for faster training)

  • OS: Ubuntu 20.04+ or equivalent

docs.text:

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with the Image Classifier in just a few minutes!

docs.title: Using Default Configuration
docs.text:
The simplest way to start:

python src/training/train.py

This will:

  • Download the CIFAR-10 dataset automatically
  • Train a simple CNN model
  • Save the best model to models/
  • Generate reports in reports/

docs.title: Training Output
docs.text:
You'll see output like this:

================================================================================
Configuration:
data:
  batch_size: 64
  name: cifar10
  num_classes: 10
hyperparameters:
  learning_rate: 0.001
  num_epochs: 50
...
================================================================================

Using device: cuda

Loading cifar10 dataset...
Train batches: 704
Val batches: 79
Test batches: 157

Creating simple_cnn model...
Total parameters: 1,234,567
Trainable parameters: 1,234,567

Starting training for 50 epochs...

docs.title: Change Learning Rate
docs.text: python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.01

docs.title: Use Different Model
docs.text: python src/training/train.py model=resnet

docs.title: Train on MNIST Instead
docs.text: python src/training/train.py data=mnist

docs.title: Fast Training (for testing)
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py hyperparameters=fast

This uses: - 5 epochs instead of 50 - Larger batch size (128) - No learning rate scheduler

docs.title: View Results
docs.text: After training, check the results:

docs.title: Training Report
docs.text: cat reports/classification_report.txt

docs.title: Confusion Matrix
docs.text:
The confusion matrix is saved as an image:

# Linux/Mac
xdg-open reports/figures/confusion_matrix.png

# Mac
open reports/figures/confusion_matrix.png

# Windows
start reports/figures/confusion_matrix.png

docs.title: Training History
docs.text:
View the training curves:

# Linux/Mac
xdg-open reports/figures/training_history.png

docs.title: On a Single Image
docs.text:
python src/models/predict.py \
  --model_path models/simple_cnn_best.pth \
  --image_path path/to/your/image.jpg \
  --dataset cifar10

Example output:

Prediction: cat
Confidence: 0.9234

All class probabilities:
  airplane: 0.0012
  automobile: 0.0045
  bird: 0.0234
  cat: 0.9234
  deer: 0.0123
  ...

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
Make sure everything works:

# Run fast tests only
pytest tests/ -m "not slow"

# Run all tests
pytest tests/

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=src tests/

docs.title: Learn Configuration Management
docs.text:
Hydra makes it easy to manage experiments. Learn more:

# See all config options
python src/training/train.py --help

# Use different config group
python src/training/train.py --config-name=experiment1

Read the Configuration Guide for details.

docs.title: Experiment Tracking
docs.text:
Create a new experiment config:

mkdir -p configs/experiment

Create configs/experiment/my_experiment.yaml:

# @package _global_

defaults:
  - override /model: resnet
  - override /hyperparameters: default

hyperparameters:
  learning_rate: 0.005
  num_epochs: 30
  batch_size: 128

experiment_name: my_first_experiment

Run it:

python src/training/train.py --config-name=experiment/my_experiment

docs.title: Use Docker
docs.text:
Train in a container:

# Build image
docker build -t image-classifier .

# Run training
docker run --rm \
  -v $(pwd)/models:/app/models \
  -v $(pwd)/reports:/app/reports \
  image-classifier

docs.title: Version Your Data
docs.text:
Track datasets with DVC:

# Initialize DVC
dvc init

# Track data
dvc add data/raw

# Commit to git
git add data/raw.dvc .dvc/config
git commit -m "Track data with DVC"

docs.title: Workflow 1: Quick Iteration
docs.text:
# Fast training for debugging
python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters=fast \
  hyperparameters.num_epochs=2

# Check results
cat reports/classification_report.txt

docs.title: Workflow 2: Production Training
docs.text:
# Full training with best settings
python src/training/train.py \
  model=resnet \
  hyperparameters.num_epochs=100 \
  hyperparameters.learning_rate=0.001 \
  hyperparameters.use_scheduler=true

docs.title: Workflow 3: Hyperparameter Search
docs.text:
# Try different learning rates
for lr in 0.0001 0.001 0.01; do
  python src/training/train.py \
    hyperparameters.learning_rate=$lr \
    experiment_name=lr_search_$lr
done

docs.title: Monitor GPU Usage
docs.text:
# While training, in another terminal:
watch -n 1 nvidia-smi

docs.title: Save Outputs to Custom Directory
docs.text:
python src/training/train.py \
  output_dir=./outputs/experiment_1 \
  model_save_dir=./models/experiment_1

docs.title: Use Multiple GPUs
docs.text:
PyTorch will automatically use all available GPUs. To restrict:

CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=0 python src/training/train.py

docs.title: Resume Training
docs.text: Currently not implemented, but you can add this feature! See Contributing.

docs.title: Out of Memory
docs.text:
Reduce batch size:

python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.batch_size=32

docs.title: Training Too Slow
docs.text:
Use fast config or fewer epochs:

python src/training/train.py hyperparameters.num_epochs=10

docs.title: Can't Find Model File
docs.text:
Check the model save directory:

ls -la models/

Models are saved as {model_name}_best.pth.

docs.title: CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text: This project uses GitHub Actions for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD).

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The CI/CD pipeline consists of two main workflows:

  1. Tests & Linting (tests.yaml) - Runs on every push and PR
  2. Continuous ML (cml.yaml) - Trains models and generates reports

docs.title: Triggered On
docs.text:
• Push to main or develop branches
  • Pull requests to main or develop

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[Push/PR] --> B[Setup Python]
    B --> C[Install Dependencies]
    C --> D[Lint Code]
    D --> E[Run Tests]
    E --> F[Coverage Report]

docs.title: 1. Code Quality Checks
docs.text:
Flake8 - Syntax and style checking: 

flake8 src tests --max-line-length=127

Black - Code formatting: 

black --check src tests

isort - Import sorting: 

isort --check-only src tests

mypy - Type checking: 

mypy src --ignore-missing-imports

docs.title: 2. Unit Tests
docs.text:
Runs all tests across multiple Python versions:

  • Python 3.8
  • Python 3.9
  • Python 3.10
pytest tests/ -v --tb=short -m "not slow"

docs.title: 3. Coverage Report
docs.text:
Generates code coverage and uploads to Codecov:

pytest tests/ --cov=src --cov-report=xml

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
.github/workflows/tests.yaml:

name: CI - Tests and Linting

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main, develop ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main, develop ]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        python-version: ["3.8", "3.9", "3.10"]
    # ... (see full file)

docs.title: Triggered On
docs.text:
• Push to main or develop
  • Pull requests to main

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Trigger] --> B[Setup Environment]
    B --> C[Train Model]
    C --> D[Generate Metrics]
    D --> E[Create Confusion Matrix]
    E --> F[Generate Report]
    F --> G[Post PR Comment]

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Setup Environment
  2. Install Python and dependencies

  3. Pull data with DVC (if configured)

  4. Train Model 

    python src/training/train.py \
  hyperparameters=fast \
  hyperparameters.num_epochs=3

  5. Generate Metrics

  6. Classification report
  7. Confusion matrix

  8. Training history plots

  9. Create CML Report

  10. Compiles all metrics into markdown
  11. Posts as PR comment
  12. Uploads artifacts

```

docs.title: 1. Enable GitHub Actions
docs.text:
GitHub Actions is enabled by default for public repositories.

For private repos: 1. Go to Settings → Actions → General 2. Enable "Allow all actions and reusable workflows"

docs.title: 2. Add Secrets (if needed)
docs.text:
For DVC remote storage or other services:

  1. Go to Settings → Secrets and variables → Actions
  2. Add secrets:
  3. DVC_REMOTE_URL (if using DVC)
  4. AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID (if using S3)
  5. etc.

docs.title: 3. Configure DVC Remote (Optional)
docs.text:
If using DVC:

# Local setup
dvc remote add -d storage s3://mybucket/path

# In GitHub Actions, add secret
# Then modify workflow:
- name: Configure DVC
  env:
    AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
    AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
  run: dvc pull

docs.title: Modify Test Configuration
docs.text:
Edit .github/workflows/tests.yaml:

# Change Python versions
strategy:
  matrix:
    python-version: ["3.9", "3.10", "3.11"]

# Add more lint checks
- name: Run pylint
  run: pylint src

docs.title: Modify CML Configuration
docs.text:
Edit .github/workflows/cml.yaml:

# Train for more epochs
- name: Train model
  run: |
    python src/training/train.py \
      hyperparameters.num_epochs=10

  10. Save reports for later review

  11. Use appropriate retention days

  12. Security

  13. Never commit secrets
  14. Use GitHub Secrets
  15. Limit workflow permissions

docs.title: Tests Failing Locally But Passing in CI
docs.text:
• Check Python version
  • Clear cache: pip cache purge
  • Check for environment-specific code

docs.title: CML Report Not Appearing
docs.text:
• Check GitHub token permissions
  • Verify CML installation
  • Check workflow logs

docs.title: Out of Memory in CI
docs.text:
• Reduce batch size in fast config
  • Use smaller model
  • Request more resources

docs.title: Matrix Strategy
docs.text:
Test multiple configurations:

strategy:

    python-version: [3.8, 3.9, 3.10]

Speed up workflows with caching:

docs.title: Data Versioning with DVC
docs.text: Learn how to use Data Version Control (DVC) to track datasets, models, and experiments.

docs.title: Why DVC?
docs.text:
• Version large files - Git can't handle large datasets efficiently
  • Share data - Use remote storage (S3, Google Drive, etc.)
  • Reproduce experiments - Track exact data versions
  • Save storage - Don't duplicate data across branches

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
DVC is already included in requirements.txt. If not installed:

pip install dvc dvc-gdrive  # Or dvc-s3, dvc-azure, etc.

docs.title: 1. Initialize DVC
docs.text:
dvc init
git add .dvc .dvcignore
git commit -m "Initialize DVC"

docs.title: 2. Track Data
docs.text:
# Track the data directory
dvc add data/raw

# This creates data/raw.dvc
git add data/raw.dvc data/.gitignore
git commit -m "Track data with DVC"

docs.title: 3. Setup Remote Storage
docs.text:
Choose a remote storage backend:

Google DriveAWS S3Local Storage 
dvc remote add -d storage gdrive://FOLDER_ID
git add .dvc/config
git commit -m "Configure remote storage"

dvc remote add -d storage s3://mybucket/path
dvc remote modify storage region us-west-2

dvc remote add -d storage /tmp/dvc-storage
# Or network drive
dvc remote add -d storage /mnt/shared/dvc-storage

docs.title: 4. Push Data
docs.text: dvc push

docs.title: Clone Repository and Get Data
docs.text:
# Clone repo
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git
cd repo

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Pull data
dvc pull

docs.title: Update Dataset
docs.text:
# 1. Modify your data
cp new_data/* data/raw/

# 2. Update DVC tracking
dvc add data/raw

# 3. Commit changes
git add data/raw.dvc
git commit -m "Update dataset with new images"

# 4. Push to remote
dvc push
git push

docs.title: Switch Between Versions
docs.text:
# Go to a specific commit
git checkout <commit-hash>

# Pull the corresponding data
dvc pull

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text:
# Check what's changed
dvc status

# Check DVC cache
dvc cache dir

docs.title: Track Trained Models
docs.text:
# Add models directory
dvc add models/

git add models.dvc
git commit -m "Track trained models"
dvc push

docs.title: Version Models with Experiments
docs.text:
Create a pipeline:

# dvc.yaml
stages:
  train:
    cmd: python src/training/train.py
    deps:
      - src/training/train.py
      - data/raw
    params:
      - config.yaml:hyperparameters.learning_rate
      - config.yaml:hyperparameters.num_epochs
    outs:
      - models/simple_cnn_best.pth
    metrics:
      - reports/classification_report.txt:
          cache: false

Run pipeline:

dvc repro

docs.title: Google Drive
docs.text:
1. Create a folder in Google Drive
  2. Get the folder ID from the URL
  3. Configure DVC:
dvc remote add -d storage gdrive://FOLDER_ID

First push will open browser for authentication.

docs.title: AWS S3
docs.text:
# Add remote
dvc remote add -d storage s3://mybucket/path

# Configure credentials
dvc remote modify storage access_key_id YOUR_KEY
dvc remote modify storage secret_access_key YOUR_SECRET

# Or use AWS CLI credentials
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=xxx
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=xxx

docs.title: Azure Blob Storage
docs.text:
dvc remote add -d storage azure://container/path
dvc remote modify storage account_name myaccount

docs.title: SSH/Local
docs.text:
# SSH
dvc remote add -d storage ssh://user@server:/path/to/storage

# Local or network drive
dvc remote add -d storage /mnt/shared/dvc-storage

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
Add secrets to GitHub:

  1. Go to Settings → Secrets
  2. Add necessary credentials (AWS keys, etc.)

docs.title: Workflow Example
docs.text:
name: DVC Pipeline

on: [push]

jobs:
  train:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Setup Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v4
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          pip install -r requirements.txt

      - name: Pull data
        env:
          AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
          AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
        run: |
          dvc pull

      - name: Train model
        run: |
          dvc repro

      - name: Push results
        run: |
          dvc push

docs.title: 1. Organize Data
docs.text:
data/
├── raw/           # Original immutable data - track with DVC
├── processed/     # Processed data - track with DVC
└── interim/       # Temporary data - don't track

docs.title: 2. Use .dvcignore
docs.text:
Exclude files you don't want to track:

# .dvcignore
*.log
*.tmp
__pycache__/
.ipynb_checkpoints/

docs.title: 3. Track Different Versions
docs.text:
# Tag important versions
git tag -a v1.0 -m "Dataset version 1.0"
git push --tags
dvc push

docs.title: 4. Share Specific Versions
docs.text:
# Create branch for experiment
git checkout -b experiment/new_data
dvc add data/raw
git add data/raw.dvc
git commit -m "Add new dataset"
dvc push
git push -u origin experiment/new_data

docs.title: DVC Pipelines
docs.text:
Define reproducible workflows:

# dvc.yaml
stages:
  preprocess:
    cmd: python src/data/preprocess.py
    deps:
      - data/raw
    outs:
      - data/processed

  train:
    cmd: python src/training/train.py
    deps:
      - data/processed
      - src/training/train.py
    params:
      - configs/config.yaml:hyperparameters
    outs:
      - models/model.pth
    metrics:
      - reports/metrics.json:
          cache: false

Run entire pipeline:

dvc repro

docs.title: Experiments
docs.text:
Track experiments:

# Run experiment
dvc exp run

# Compare experiments
dvc exp show

# Apply best experiment
dvc exp apply <exp-name>

docs.title: Metrics Tracking
docs.text:
# dvc.yaml
stages:
  train:
    metrics:
      - reports/metrics.json:
          cache: false
    plots:
      - reports/confusion_matrix.png:
          cache: false

Compare metrics:

dvc metrics show
dvc metrics diff

docs.title: Large Files Not Tracked
docs.text:
Check .gitignore:

cat data/.gitignore
# Should contain /raw (added by dvc add)

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
For remote storage, check credentials:

dvc remote list
dvc remote modify storage --local access_key_id YOUR_KEY

docs.title: Cache Issues
docs.text:
Clear and rebuild cache:

dvc cache dir  # Show cache location
rm -rf .dvc/cache
dvc pull

docs.title: Slow Push/Pull
docs.text:
Use parallel transfers:

dvc config cache.type symlink
dvc push --jobs 4

docs.title: DVC vs Git LFS
docs.text: Feature DVC Git LFS Storage backends Many (S3, Azure, GDrive, SSH, etc.) Git LFS server Versioning Full versioning Full versioning Pipeline support Yes No Metrics tracking Yes No Free tier Depends on storage GitHub: 1GB
